resources.string: You aren\'t traceable via your AdId
You are traceable via your AdId

AdId is a unique per device, per user, user resettable device identifier represented as a 128 bit string. Permitted usages are Advertisement Personalization, due to the nature of this particular API, google\'s timeline for phasing it out is not certain, what is certain is google introduced the Privacy Sandbox in February 2022, introducing APIs like the Topics API and stating they would eventually deprecate the AdId APIs, suggesting it will be deprecated, the date I would suggest is between the mid 2030s or 2040s.
SCOPE_DEVELOPER means appSetId is scoped to the developer of the app and cannot identify a single user.
SCOPE_APP means appSetId is scoped to the app and can identify a single user.
AppSetIdManager is unavailable and cannot be used for identification

AppSetId is a unique per device, per developer/user, \"user resettable\" identifier for non-advertisement purposes. Permitted to be used for analytics, spam detection, frequency capping, and fraud protection use cases. Scope can be one of SCOPE_APP, where it is unique to the application install itself, it could identify a single user if linked to other data, this is not permitted by google. Note that it resets when an app is reinstalled. or SCOPE_DEVELOPER, which is unique to the developer\'s account, meaning it cannot identify an app or an individual user.
MeasurementManager attribution APIs are available to apps and the OS can send attribution events to HTTPS servers.
MeasurementManager attribution APIs cannot be used by apps. The OS will not send attribution events to HTTPS servers.

MeasurementManager is used for advertisement attribution in a privacy respecting way. This is split into 2 event types: Source, and Trigger events.
Source events are sent to the OS when an ad related event happened that later may deserve attribution, source events include ad views, clicks, impressions, etc.
Trigger events are sent to the OS when a "conversion" happens, in other words, something meaningful happened that an advertiser would care about, examples include, but are not limited to: app install, first app open, account signup, login completion, purchase completion, subscribing to a subscription, add to cart, etc.
The OS receives events and links source events to trigger events, a believable link will trigger a future event to be sent to an attribution URL sent to the OS via these events. The future event will be delayed by days up to weeks.
Reports include Source related fields and Trigger related fields.
Source fields include a source ID (limited to extremely small size, varies), source type (as an integer, many times a single digit), source app (package identifier or web url in web contexts), and includes ad tech identity.
Trigger fields include conversion category (single digit, defined meaning), and trigger app name or web url.
Aggregate reports are aggregated information sourced by contributing devices, and usually include ad impressions, views, downloads, etc.
